data16.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data16.txt.title: Buddha or Karl Marx
data16.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 3
data16.txt.section: Comparative Analysis of Buddhism and Marxism
themes: Ends vs Means in Social Change
data16.txt.abstract: A comparative philosophical analysis in which Ambedkar evaluates the ideological foundations, aims, and methods of Buddhism and Marxism. While recognizing common goals such as the elimination of suffering and exploitation, Ambedkar contrasts the Buddha’s ethical, non-violent, and moral method of social reconstruction with Marxism’s reliance on violence and proletarian dictatorship. The essay argues for moral transformation as the superior means of achieving social justice.

data17.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data17.txt.title: Buddha or Karl Marx
data17.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 3
data17.txt.section: Evaluation of Means: Violence, Dictatorship, and Moral Force
data17.txt.category: Political Philosophy / Ethics of Social Change
themes: Government by Force vs Government by Moral Disposition
Moral Force as Lasting Social Foundation
Rule by Righteousness vs Rule by Law
Ethical Decline from Poverty and Injustice
data17.txt.abstract: This section evaluates the means employed by Buddhism and Communism in achieving social transformation. Ambedkar argues that while both traditions seek the removal of suffering and exploitation, their methods fundamentally diverge. Communism relies on violence and dictatorship, which destroy liberty and moral ends in the process of reform. Buddhism, by contrast, emphasizes moral force, justice, and democratic principles. Drawing on Buddhist dialogues and parables, Ambedkar demonstrates that durable social order cannot be sustained through coercion, but only through ethical training and voluntary moral discipline.

data18.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data18.txt.title: Buddha or Karl Marx
data18.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 3
data18.txt.section: Critique of Permanent Dictatorship and the Withering of the State
data18.txt.category: Political Philosophy / State, Religion, and Social Sustainability
themes: Role of Religion in Sustaining Society
Buddhism as Synthesis of Liberty, Equality, Fraternity
data18.txt.abstract: In this section, Ambedkar critically examines the Communist claim that the State will eventually wither away under permanent dictatorship. He argues that coercion cannot sustain a social order once force is withdrawn and that moral and spiritual foundations are indispensable for long-term stability. Contrasting Communist hostility to religion with Buddhism’s ethical and worldly orientation, Ambedkar shows how the Buddha reconciled material prosperity with moral discipline. He concludes that while Communism may achieve equality, only the Buddhist path can harmonize equality with liberty and fraternity, making social reconstruction durable and humane.

data19.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data19.txt.title: Castes in India: Their Mechanism, Genesis and Development
data19.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 1
data19.txt.context: Anthropological and Sociological Analysis of the Caste System
themes: Critique of Racial Explanations of Caste
data19.txt.abstract: This early academic paper presents Ambedkar’s foundational analysis of the Indian caste system using an ethnological and sociological framework. Rejecting racial and purely religious explanations, Ambedkar argues that caste represents the parcelling of an originally homogeneous society. Through a critical review of prevailing definitions of caste, he demonstrates that endogamy—rather than occupation, race, or ritual purity—is the central mechanism governing caste formation, persistence, and expansion.

data20.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data20.txt.title: Castes in India: Their Mechanism, Genesis and Development
data20.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 1
data20.txt.context: Anthropological and Sociological Analysis of the Caste System
data20.txt.section: Endogamy as the Essence and Mechanism of Caste
themes: Critique of Existing Definitions of Caste
Caste as a System, Not an Isolated Unit
Effect vs Cause in Caste Practices
data20.txt.abstract: In this section, Ambedkar advances his central thesis that endogamy is the defining essence of caste in India. Rejecting occupation, ritual purity, and food restrictions as secondary effects, he argues that caste arises from the deliberate superposition of endogamy upon an originally exogamous and culturally homogeneous society. Ambedkar then identifies the core practical problem of caste maintenance—the regulation of marriageable units—and shows how surplus men and women pose a structural threat to caste continuity. This analysis lays the groundwork for explaining the social controls developed to preserve caste boundaries.

data21.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data21.txt.title: Castes in India: Their Mechanism, Genesis and Development
data21.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 1
data21.txt.context: Anthropological and Sociological Analysis of the Caste System
data21.txt.section: Control of Surplus Men and Women: Social Mechanisms Preserving Endogamy
data21.txt.category: Sociology / Anthropology / Gender and Social Institutions
data21.txt.abstract: In this section, Ambedkar completes his scientific explanation of caste by identifying the concrete social mechanisms devised to preserve endogamy. He shows how surplus women and surplus men threaten caste continuity and how Hindu society developed gendered solutions—Sati, enforced widowhood, celibacy, and child marriage—to regulate marriageable units. Ambedkar argues that these practices were not moral ideals but functional instruments for maintaining caste boundaries. Customs long justified through religious philosophy are thus revealed as structural devices essential to the survival of the caste system.

data22.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data22.txt.title: Castes in India: Their Mechanism, Genesis and Development
data22.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 1
data22.txt.context: Anthropological and Sociological Analysis of the Caste System
data22.txt.section: Genesis and Spread of Caste: Enclosed Class and Social Imitation
themes: Means vs Ideals in Social Institutions
Endogamy as Defining Feature of Caste
Brahmin Class as First Enclosed Group
Critique of Divine or Scriptural Origin of Caste
Rejection of Manu as Law-Giver of Caste
Occupational and Tribal Theories of Caste
data22.txt.abstract: In this concluding section, Ambedkar distinguishes between the mechanism, genesis, and spread of caste. He argues that customs such as Sati, enforced widowhood, and child marriage were functional means later idealized through philosophy. Defining caste as an enclosed class, he identifies the Brahmin class as the first group to institutionalize endogamy, with other castes adopting similar practices through social imitation rather than coercion or divine legislation. Ambedkar decisively rejects scriptural, law-giver, and great-man theories of caste, establishing caste as a socially evolved institution sustained by imitation, rationalization, and structural necessity rather than conscious design.

data23.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data23.txt.title: Castes in India: Their Mechanism, Genesis and Development
data23.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 1
data23.txt.context: Anthropological and Sociological Analysis of the Caste System
data23.txt.section: Spread of Caste through Social Imitation and Prestige Hierarchy
themes: Critique of Occupational Theories of Caste
Rejection of Naturalistic and Evolutionary Explanations
Transition from Open Class to Closed Caste
Endogamy as Fashion and Social Norm
Sati, Widowhood, and Child Marriage as Imitated Practices
data23.txt.abstract: In this section, Ambedkar develops the psychological explanation for the spread of caste in India. Rejecting occupational, evolutionary, and naturalistic theories, he argues that caste emerged when open social classes became endogamous through imitation of the Brahmin caste. Drawing on Gabriel Tarde’s laws of imitation, Ambedkar shows how prestige, proximity, and hierarchical influence led non-Brahmin classes to copy Brahmin social practices, including endogamy and associated customs. Caste formation is thus explained as a process of social emulation rather than divine command, natural evolution, or conscious coercion.

data24.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data24.txt.title: Castes in India: Their Mechanism, Genesis and Development
data24.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches, Vol. 1
data24.txt.context: Anthropological and Sociological Analysis of the Caste System
data24.txt.section: Mechanistic Formation of Castes and Final Synthesis
data24.txt.category: Sociology / Anthropology / Theory of Social Stratification
themes: Caste as a System, Not an Isolated Unit
Creation of New Castes through Exclusion
Critique of Racial Theories of Caste
Rejection of Colour as Basis of Caste
Imitation and Excommunication as Dual Forces
Theory of Caste as Provisional and Testable
data24.txt.abstract: In this concluding section, Ambedkar introduces the mechanistic explanation of caste formation, showing how groups become castes not only by closing themselves in, but also by being forcibly closed out through excommunication. He emphasizes that caste exists only as a system of multiple interacting units and is inherently self-duplicating. Rejecting racial, occupational, and colour-based explanations, Ambedkar synthesizes his argument around cultural unity, endogamy, imitation, and exclusion. He concludes by positioning his theory as a scientific contribution—open to revision—aimed at redirecting caste studies toward objective, structural analysis rather than sentiment or scriptural justification.

data25.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
data25.txt.title: What Congress and Gandhi Have Done to the Untouchables
data25.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar: Writings and Speeches
data25.txt.context: Critique of Congress Politics and Gandhian Approach to Untouchability
data25.txt.section: Gandhi, Congress, and the Denial of Political Rights to Untouchables
data25.txt.category: Political History / Dalit Politics / Indian National Movement
themes: Temple Entry and Water Rights Movements
Fast unto Death as Political Coercion
data25.txt.abstract: In this section, Ambedkar delivers a sharp political critique of Mahatma Gandhi and the Indian National Congress for their failure to genuinely address untouchability. He documents Gandhi’s refusal to employ Satyagraha or fasting against caste Hindus, even while Untouchables endured violence during temple-entry and water-rights movements. Ambedkar argues that social reform without political power had repeatedly failed and that Untouchables therefore required constitutional safeguards. He critically examines Gandhi’s opposition to separate political representation for Untouchables at the Round Table Conference and interprets the Poona Pact as a coerced compromise that ultimately weakened Dalit political autonomy.

speech9.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
speech9.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Writings and Speeches, Vol. 2
speech9.txt.title: Speech on Prohibition
speech9.txt.context: In this legislative speech, Dr. B. R. Ambedkar critiques the Excise Minister’s approach to prohibition in the Bombay Presidency. While supporting the moral objective of prohibition, he argues that excessively high excise tariffs on country liquor incentivize illicit production and consumption, thereby defeating the policy’s purpose. Drawing on principles of political economy, Ambedkar emphasizes that prohibition cannot succeed without a sound fiscal strategy to replace lost excise revenue. He stresses the necessity of progressive taxation, urging the government to tax those with greater capacity to pay, and insists that additional taxation is justifiable only if used for nation-building and public welfare rather than mere administrative maintenance.

speech10.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
speech10.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Writings and Speeches, Vol. 2
speech10.txt.title: Speech on Punishment of Whipping Bill
speech10.txt.category: Criminal Law / Penal Policy / Public Order
speech10.txt.context: In this speech, Dr. B. R. Ambedkar evaluates the Punishment of Whipping Bill and accepts neither the novelty nor the legitimacy of whipping as punishment as the core issue, since whipping already existed in Indian law. His primary concern is the excessive breadth of the bill, which seeks to apply whipping to all forms of rioting under the Indian Penal Code. Ambedkar argues that whipping, being an extreme punishment, should be restricted strictly to communal riots and not extended to ordinary riots arising from industrial disputes or minor civil conflicts. He emphasizes proportionality, legal precision, and the dangers of indiscriminate penal expansion, reflecting his legal-philosophical commitment to restrained and purpose-specific criminal legislation.

speech11.txt.author: B. R. Ambedkar
speech11.txt.source: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Writings and Speeches, Vol. 2
speech11.txt.title: Speech on Tobacco Duty Act Amendment Bill
speech11.txt.category: Fiscal Policy / Parliamentary Procedure / Taxation Law
themes: Estoppel and waiver in legislative practice
Limits of executive power in finance matters
speech11.txt.context: In this speech, Dr. B. R. Ambedkar intervenes in a procedural dispute concerning the Tobacco Duty Act Amendment Bill, focusing on whether the bill should be treated as a Finance Bill or merely as legislation regulating administrative machinery for taxation. He rejects the argument that prior approval of other taxes creates waiver or estoppel against further debate, asserting the independent authority of the House to grant or refuse supplies. Ambedkar demonstrates that the primary object of the bill is revenue generation—specifically to offset losses from prohibition policy—thereby qualifying it as a Finance Bill. His intervention highlights his deep engagement with parliamentary procedure, fiscal responsibility, and the constitutional principle that taxation must remain under effective legislative control.
